6E5071E152E34A3090A36AEC111EE990.description: state Bernoulli's principle, and explain some of its applications (e.g., spray atomizers, propellers, spoilers on racing cars, turbine blades in jet engines)

9A87469D372149C1931C7317371E9987.description: describe factors affecting laminar flow, and explain how the design of an item or organism (e.g., cars, boats, planes, turbine blades, propellers, golf balls, swimsuits, sharks) responds to these factors

27BA7F8BCFD442A8922466976BB61454.description: describe common components used in hydraulic and pneumatic systems (e.g., cylinders, valves, motors, fluids, hoses, connectors, pumps, reservoirs), and explain their function

7193C542D00A40B8975463AA4204E6F7.description: state Pascal's principle, and explain its applications in the transmission of forces in fluid systems

978AD54755F2494F9E8550D78F435FAB.description: identify factors affecting static pressure head (e.g., variations in Earth's atmosphere), analyse static pressure head in quantitative terms, and explain its effects in liquids and gases

4A3D0CC7956D4B9DB0717D5990E378A4.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of the scientific principles related to fluid statics, fluid dynamics, and hydraulic and pneumatic systems

53C4C41418EB4D38B9419416CEBC9EF2.description: conduct an inquiry to demonstrate Bernoulli's principle (e.g., using a wind tunnel or Venturi tube, suspending a table tennis ball in an air current, blowing between pieces of paper)

B66382427AB64A72B8083ECE69EE3FEC.description: design and construct a hydraulic or pneumatic system (e.g., a braking system for a car, a clamping device, a model of a crane), solving problems as they arise, and evaluate the system with respect to mechanical advantage and efficiency

58736BBAC2884B7F9DF00C51589DF820.description: solve problems related to the relationships between force, area, pressure, volume, and time in hydraulic and pneumatic systems (e.g., the force exerted on the wheel of a motor vehicle by the hydraulically operated brake pad; the time required for a robotic system to complete one cycle of operation)

9ACA55977D8640F494941C0FC889F0DB.description: use an inquiry process to determine the relationships between force, area, pressure, volume, and time in a hydraulic or pneumatic system (e.g., a hydraulic bottle rocket, a twocylinder circuit using small plastic syringes filled with air or water)

45F99D9C21A84ACC9842E9A6C7A5DE03.description: conduct a laboratory inquiry or computer simulation to demonstrate Pascal's principle

B31DB68F18304EBEAEF2A2A70485765A.description: use an inquiry process to determine factors that affect the static pressure head in fluids, compare theoretical and empirical values, and account for discrepancies

AF94AFDB3FCA4C24BD5408DF777516D3.description: draw simple hydraulic or pneumatic circuits

C3B70E7D6840407C8CB06A6F03E489BD.description: use appropriate terminology related to hydraulic and pneumatic systems, including, but not limited to: density, atmospheric pressure, absolute pressure, laminar flow, turbulent flow, static pressure, pressure, volume, and flow rate

39C497A1F0FE4964B86A6FE82B768935.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate fluid statics, fluid dynamics, and simple hydraulic and pneumatic systems;

B0AF5C711B6B45DF9A7C4395C8353D4D.description: analyse some of the social and economic consequences of the use of robotic systems for different kinds of operations (e.g., in the manufacturing of computers, for lifting and manoeuvring heavy objects on assembly lines, for handling hazardous materials, for activities under water and in space)

8399B5B48A7E44569F11FF26E45DE67B.description: research the historical development of a pneumatic or hydraulic system used in a specific technology (e.g., the hydraulic system in aircraft or other vehicles or in precision machining; the pneumatic system in an air motor or robotics), analyse the original design, and determine why the technology was developed and how it has been improved

7E69BBECBE644C1E9D1EF3CC75806D27.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: analyse the development of technological applications related to hydraulic and pneumatic systems, and assess some of the social and environmental effects of these systems;

B3500FCB06C94DA7922241047AC48781.description: describe a variety of renewable and nonrenewable sources of energy (e.g., solar energy, fossil fuels, hydroelectric energy, energy generated from biomass), and identify the strengths and weaknesses of each

333A6CDF67094AAAA11245D81A41C300.description: compare the efficiency of various systems that produce electricity (e.g., wind farms, hydroelectric generators, solar panels), using the law of conservation of energy, and outlining the transformations, transmissions, and energy losses involved

3AE701CD6D8941B49FC2A5A1E1504FC5.description: describe, with the aid of diagrams, the operation of selected energy-transformation technologies (e.g., wind turbines, photoelectric cells, heat engines)

7CDAE21161A54150AE2086221528EAEA.description: explain the energy transformations in a system (e.g., a toy, an amusement park ride, a skydiver suspended from a parachute), using principles related to kinetic energy, gravitational potential energy, conservation of energy, and efficiency

1A30301B6FC944DFA17F60B436D9FCA3.description: describe and compare various types of energy and energy transformations (e.g., transformations related to kinetic, sound, electric, chemical, potential, mechanical, nuclear, and thermal energy)

56B8941E590A4547B57508F151B46F1C.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of diverse forms of energy, energy transformations, and efficiency.

D56FB7C7C4914A1EA59071EED65ACE9E.description: investigate a simple energy transformation (e.g., the use of an elastic band to propel a miniature car), explain the power and output, and calculate the energy

75CDCE432AC84C719AABD4A4A1618112.description: design and construct a complex device that integrates energy transformations (e.g., a mousetrap vehicle, an "egg-drop" container, a wind turbine), and analyse its operation in qualitative and quantitative terms

94ADD76AA0E247908E8E5B227CE1EBA0.description: construct a simple device that makes use of energy transformations (e.g., a pendulum, a roller coaster), and use it to investigate transformations between gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy

346F2446FA62499FAA05B1EF591ACF79.description: use the law of conservation of energy to solve problems involving gravitational potential energy, kinetic energy, and thermal energy

B7ACD2AF2F224A399415F090FCAD24E5.description: use appropriate terminology related to energy and energy transformations, including, but not limited to: work, gravitational potential energy, kinetic energy, chemical energy, energy transformations, and efficiency

2C9F3FC6E17345E992FE0C635D1C1CB0.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate energy transformations and the law of conservation of energy, and solve related problems;

B1824FC17EC24D67B71C2EACC491C6D6.description: propose a course of practical action to improve the sustainability of an energy-transformation technology (e.g., solar panels, internal combustion engines, fuel cells, air conditioners)

7E4FBFC011B34725AB4E8FFCCB41F3BF.description: analyse an energy-transformation technology (e.g., wind turbines, refrigerators, telephones, steam engines, coal-fired electrical plants), and evaluate its impact on society and the environment

B361FE6917CD49598999C7A61DAD8173.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: evaluate the impact on society and the environment of energy-transformation technologies, and propose ways to improve the sustainability of one such technology;

7EAEA3A084FD44B094F906E79174EFF7.description: compare and contrast direct current and alternating current (AC) in qualitative terms (e.g., the difference between DC and AC motors), and describe situations in which each is used

B00CF4A012A242048A982CA3BF5309C1.description: explain, using diagrams, the components and operation of a DC electric motor

2E39CB0AC3BE4FA0B8CC8997D515A793.description: state the motor principle, and use the righthand rule to explain the direction of the force experienced by a conductor

38494F4EECE046D8A09BB73F7D63BDCD.description: state Oersted's principle, and apply the right-hand rule to explain the direction of the magnetic field produced when electric current flows through a long, straight conductor and through a solenoid

4EB3B636550A4CE589550BC7DB400701.description: distinguish between conventional current and electron flow

C823F79033E74FE4A25DF1A4377DB38C.description: explain the law of magnetic poles

F47C0ACE54A64AA38267602A2D410D95.description: describe, with the aid of an illustration, the magnetic field produced by permanent magnets (bar and U-shaped) and electromagnets (straight conductor and solenoid)

F9DEAC15E70145C89A71D8D02724D36E.description: identify and explain safety precautions related to electrical circuits in the school, home, and workplace (e.g., the importance of turning off the current before performing electrical repairs; the reasons for grounding circuits; how to safely replace spent fuses; the use of double insulated tools and appliance circuit breakers)

3FD0ADFB33B447259B1D9A5556AADAC3.description: state Kirchhoff's laws and Ohm's law, and use them to explain, in quantitative terms, direct current, potential difference, and resistance in mixed circuit diagrams

5CC18D7E22154C58809690D3155E6657.description: compare and contrast the behaviour and functions of series, parallel, and mixed DC circuits

CFFDD366AD9243D286091471E78B9CBA.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of the basic principles of electricity and magnetism.

EC4C81A22F3B4F768C0DA7FBE059DDFB.description: construct, or deconstruct and explain the components of, a basic electric device (e.g., a DC motor, a water-level detector)

418C0A4277494BE6A6113F7E4D42A710.description: conduct an inquiry to determine the direction of the forces on a straight current-carrying conductor that is placed in a uniform magnetic field

2E14672072F9489C8DC9949A0D316814.description: conduct an inquiry to determine the direction of the magnetic field of a straight current-carrying conductor or solenoid

C775D35B3B244BA79B2FD0B941FCE0C1.description: conduct an inquiry to determine the magnetic fields produced by a permanent magnet, a straight current-carrying conductor, and a solenoid, and illustrate their findings

B63F08462D00456D918889BBF5D5D200.description: analyse, in quantitative terms, real or simulated DC circuits and circuit diagrams, using Ohm's law and Kirchhoff's laws

24E87E5AD223435F94770421BD49CE69.description: construct real and simulated mixed direct current (DC) circuits (i.e., parallel, series, and mixed circuits), and analyse them in quantitative terms to test Kirchhoff's laws

72E4EE041F474C8C9D6C97879AD4B8F3.description: use appropriate terminology related to electricity and magnetism, including, but not limited to: direct current, alternating current, electrical potential difference, resistance, power, energy, permanent magnet, electromagnet, magnetic field, motor principle, and electric motor

E51C91B2EFC840389F1E7E873E3D38CF.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate real and simulated mixed direct current circuits and the nature of magnetism and electromagnetism, and analyse related data;

17ADD36458B54A31AD6B79D20E1AFBD8.description: assess the impact of an electromagnetic technology that is used for the benefit of society or the environment (e.g., devices for diagnosing and treating diseases, technologies for treating seeds to increase the rate of germination)

AFEF596D3FC64F5AB5E7D7BCAEFCCE13.description: evaluate, on the basis of research, the impact on society and the environment of the evolution of an electrical technology (e.g., electric cars or buses, electric appliances)

2DFCAF749EE54E75A32A5EBF95E58636.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: analyse the development of selected electrical and electromagnetic technologies, and evaluate their impact on society and the environment;

95488C729ACB42E781B9B54A36460F71.description: explain the concept of mechanical advantage

CE34AB956968476F91C652C15F7F894E.description: explain, with reference to force and displacement, the conditions necessary for work to be done

9A5D5A04812B4537AA8D565548CA19BA.description: explain the operation and mechanical advantage of compound machines and biomechanical systems (e.g., block-and-tackle, winch, chainand-sprocket systems; the human leg, arm)

5F94A45D3AF7426EBDAA649B385B9029.description: identify and describe, in quantitative and qualitative terms, applications of various types of simple machines (e.g., wedges, screws, levers, pulleys, gears, wheels and axles)

99A6F10F72854BABA835A03DCD596701.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of concepts related to forces and mechanical advantage in relation to mechanical systems

CA1FB89DF4B244B488A6402A8D3DEE89.description: construct a simple or compound machine, and determine its mechanical advantage (e.g., a pulley, a mobile, a can crusher, a trebuchet)

722F57BA353B4DA58150A3D69A012F87.description: investigate, in quantitative terms, common machines (e.g., a bicycle, a can opener, a piano) with respect to input and output forces and mechanical advantage

D42776BED8BE41F49EB14248D23444AD.description: solve problems involving torque, force, loadarm length, and effort-arm length as they relate to the three classes of levers

12D5B3EB37BC4FD7A178A9D5E870C3EB.description: use an inquiry process to determine the relationships between force, distance, and torque for the load arm and effort arm of lever

003BAFB7609F4BC1B1CC8316B0E24EA6.description: use an inquiry process to determine the factors affecting static and kinetic friction, and to determine the corresponding coefficient of friction between an everyday object and the surface with which it is in contact

6FE6DECBD3244079BB89F19C78E89A5F.description: analyse, in qualitative and quantitative terms, the forces (e.g., gravitational, frictional, and normal forces; tension) acting on an object in one dimension, and describe the resulting motion of the object

272396D30B8F497B8F5271D560461C74.description: use appropriate terminology related to mechanical systems, including, but not limited to: coefficients of friction, torque, mechanical advantage, work input, and work output

CE7D538B7C754270B7B427CC4081CB7D.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate forces, torque, work, coefficients of friction, simple machines, and mechanical advantage, and interpret related data

009A1BFC53714AC691D5D9D63C6DDCA2.description: evaluate, on the basis of research, the effectiveness of a common mechanical system in addressing a social or environmental challenge (e.g., prosthetic devices, bathtub lifts, high-efficiency heating and cooling systems)

70CF43EB58CB47978E40B34664FAB2F6.description: analyse advantages and disadvantages of friction within mechanical systems in real-world situations, as well as methods used to increase or reduce friction in these systems (e.g., advantages of, and methods for increasing, friction on the surface of car tires and the soles of hiking boots; disadvantages of, and methods for reducing, friction between moving parts of artificial joints)

7E3443593D114ADEB45E8FD2ACBC9070.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: analyse common mechanical systems that use friction and applied forces, and evaluate their effectiveness in meeting social or environmental challenges;

2F26D3C0029A459ABDFF7B84C65405BC.description: explain the relationship between the acceleration of an object and the net unbalanced force acting on that object

5B741A22B3794F0CAA17E0D489B2ED4B.description: state Newton's laws, and apply them qualitatively and quantitatively to explain the motion of an object in one dimension

866F81137B9A4474B0B80CAD3BFC276E.description: describe, in quantitative terms, the relationship between one-dimensional average acceleration (aav), change in speed (Δv), and elapsed time (Δt)

D49595EE455748759627B829D01F4598.description: describe the relationship between onedimensional average speed (vav), distance (Δd), and elapsed time (Δt)

CFCF1B9964D143F791CC6CB52FE2FC95.description: distinguish between constant, instantaneous, and average speed, and give examples of each involving uniform and non-uniform motion

2064634F342D4677A207EF680B00756B.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of different kinds of motion and the relationships between speed, acceleration, displacement, and distance.

6463E2891AAF49BEBFA1CA4C119B721E.description: conduct an inquiry to measure gravitational acceleration, and calculate the percentage error of the experimental value

8D7A20CA124D4FA882F9F8D8942E2802.description: analyse, in quantitative terms, the forces acting on an object, and use free-body diagrams to determine net force and acceleration of the object in one dimension

3D4D5B23B09A403F9CD6A792F857EED9.description: plan and conduct an inquiry to determine the relationship between the net force acting on an object and its acceleration in one dimension

F82241D52BEC492AA83BBC52EAF3271A.description: solve simple problems involving onedimensional average acceleration (aav), change in speed (Δv), and elapsed time (Δt) using the algebraic equation aav = Δv/Δt [AI]

3918F401CB9448CCAC95E7BB57822971.description: solve simple problems involving onedimensional average speed (vav), distance (?d), and elapsed time (?t), using the algebraic equation vav = ?d/?t [AI]

B8B1D795BFC34C6DAE5D226C013DE877.description: draw speed-time graphs, and use the graphs to calculate average acceleration and distance of objects moving in one dimension

C03C378F02BD4D2EA9DAFDF21E319C6B.description: draw distance-time graphs, and use the graphs to calculate average speed and instantaneous speed of objects moving in one dimension

ADA8D34F9BBF44DABD866FFAF5DD1E9A.description: plan and conduct investigations to measure constant acceleration for objects moving in one dimension

75E0BEDE43D1492FA6BBD5758A16DB6D.description: plan and conduct investigations to measure distance and speed for objects moving in one dimension in uniform motion

EB30AF7007F24F7BA75498D80B4253D9.description: use appropriate terminology related to motion, including, but not limited to: distance, displacement, position, speed, acceleration, instantaneous, force, and net force

033BE14D77F747128348EFDE73BC435F.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate, in qualitative and quantitative terms, the linear uniform and non-uniform motion of objects, and solve related problems;

9F62A8B51E1F4BF9A9EB3499341BCCA6.description: analyse how technologies are used to track the motion of objects, and outline various kinds of scientific knowledge gained through the use of such technologies (e.g., data on animal populations and migrations, on changes in ocean currents related to global warming, on the behaviour of celestial objects)

7F117E68279B46A2BD17336079F4C9B7.description: analyse the design and uses of a transportation technology (e.g., snowmobiles, automobiles, motorized personal water craft), and evaluate its social and environmental impact, including the impact on risk behaviour and accident rates

DB834669798C482B83D3656B51643F88.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: analyse selected technologies that are used to move objects or track their motion, and evaluate their impact on society and the environment, including their contribution to scientific knowledge;

D99DCF6A6BE1425CA83C982CDF03722C.description: describe the contributions of scientists, including Canadians (e.g., Elijah McCoy, Jaisel Vadgama, Gerald Vincent Bull, Elizabeth Cannon, Richard Marceau, Normand C. Beaulieu), to the fields under study

D9A6B8774FB3431F9573A234FADDC59E.description: identify and describe a variety of careers related to the fields of science under study (e.g., alternative energy advocate, sustainable energy technician, electrician, mechanic) and the education and training necessary for these careers

BC6722E4F72142CBA8CC8A93C12EAD89.description: Career Exploration: identify and describe careers related to the fields of science under study, and describe the contributions of scientists, including Canadians, to those fields.

01BC1DEB51E84352A37AA5029E0E99C1.description: express the results of any calculations involving data accurately and precisely, to the appropriate number of decimal places or significant figures

5379F948CFA04C37A55EF16FAD01E74A.description: use appropriate numeric (e.g., SI and imperial units), symbolic, and graphic modes of representation (e.g., free-body diagrams, algebraic equations)

027B182DBBC24013AC393EDCE91500DF.description: communicate ideas, plans, procedures, results, and conclusions orally, in writing, and/or in electronic presentations, using appropriate language and a variety of formats (e.g., data tables, laboratory reports, presentations, debates, simulations, models)

C82F31B9C528471E9DD74C3A6B64451E.description: draw conclusions based on inquiry results and research findings, and justify their conclusions with reference to scientific knowledge

2A92A0747E3746EEAA2AED42623A1FA3.description: analyse the information gathered from research sources for logic, accuracy, reliability, adequacy, and bias

F2195AC7012C4FA992873092772163D5.description: synthesize, analyse, interpret, and evaluate qualitative and/or quantitative data; solve problems using quantitative data; determine whether the evidence supports or refutes the initial prediction or hypothesis and whether it is consistent with scientific theory; identify sources of bias and/or error; and suggest improvements to the inquiry to reduce the likelihood of error

75BF33D9D7C04E5E9EBFF24A3416352D.description: select, organize, and record relevant information on research topics from a variety of appropriate sources, including electronic, print, and/or human sources, using suitable formats and an accepted form of academic documentation

35D56EF9EAEF4827A06067CD6DDAF4D4.description: compile accurate data from laboratory and other sources, and organize and record the data, using appropriate formats, including tables, flow charts, graphs, and/or diagrams

E07852109EB24388B5544F3608483C96.description: conduct inquiries, controlling relevant variables, adapting or extending procedures as required, and using appropriate materials and equipment safely, accurately, and effectively, to collect observations and data

411F012FF4F24F4883B34C59FF830B9B.description: apply knowledge and understanding of safe laboratory practices and procedures when planning investigations by correctly interpreting Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS) symbols; by using appropriate techniques for handling and storing laboratory equipment and materials and disposing of laboratory materials; and by using appropriate personal protection (e.g., personal protective equipment when carrying out fluids experiments)

C3B86223BDB147899BB8A6605DC464DE.description: identify and locate a variety of print and electronic sources that enable them to address research topics fully and appropriately

5B101A690FD64CDDAF950C95DF20E588.description: select appropriate instruments (e.g., electronic probes, pendulums, cylinders) and materials (e.g., motion carts, magnets, simple machines), and identify appropriate methods, techniques, and procedures, for each inquiry

2F2FEE29F50E4262A61EF0193A70DB50.description: formulate relevant scientific questions about observed relationships, ideas, problems, or issues, make informed predictions, and/or formulate educated hypotheses to focus inquiries or research

9120414E30474AACB97FCF27F960769B.description: Scientific Investigation Skills: demonstrate scientific investigation skills (related to both inquiry and research) in the four areas of skills (initiating and planning, performing and recording, analysing and interpreting, and communicating);

A0BC38C1A3B44A0386E2B8F217E89A8F.description: Scientific Investigation Skills and Career Exploration
